Debug

Debug presents a safe and explicit alternative to Object#toString. By providing instances of this typeclass, a type explicitly defines that it can be converted into human-readable output.

Typical imports

import scalaz.Scalaz._

Built-in instances

"Scalaz 8".debug
// res0: scalaz.data.Cord = Scalaz 8

Instance declaration

scala> import scalaz.tc.{Debug, DebugClass}
import scalaz.tc.{Debug, DebugClass}

scala> import scalaz.data.Cord
import scalaz.data.Cord

scala> case class Foo(a: Int)
defined class Foo

scala> implicit val fooDebug: Debug[Foo] =
     |   DebugClass.instance[Foo](a => Cord.wrap("Foo[", Cord(a.toString), "]"))
fooDebug: scalaz.tc.Debug[Foo] = scalaz.tc.DebugClass$$anon$1@7fcb2553

Usage

scala> val bad = Foo(1).toString
bad: String = Foo(1)

scala> val good = Foo(1).debug
good: scalaz.data.Cord = Foo[Foo(1)]

scala> import scalaz.data.Maybe
import scalaz.data.Maybe

scala> Maybe.just(Foo(1)).debug
res1: scalaz.data.Cord = Just(Foo[Foo(1)])

Note that the Debug instance for Maybe resolves against the Debug instance for Foo.

String interpolator

Scalaz contains a custom string interpolator that takes advantage of Debug. Inside the z String interpolation, only objects that have Debug instances can be used.

scala> case class Bar(a: Int)
defined class Bar

scala> val foo = Foo(123)
foo: Foo = Foo(123)

scala> val bar = Bar(234)
bar: Bar = Bar(234)

scala> val interpolated = z"${foo}"
interpolated: scalaz.data.Cord = Foo[Foo(123)]

The following fails to compile as there is no Debug instance for Bar

scala> z"${bar}"
<console>:21: error: Cannot use the `z` interpolator to interpolate a value of type Bar, as no implicit Debug[Bar] instance is in scope.
       z"${bar}"
           ^

Law

There are no laws for Debug, unlike Haskell’s Show.

Just try to keep it readable.
